title: Income and Race in New York City
text: This visualization reveals how income varies both by race and geography within New York City. The box plots show the median, quartiles, and outliers for each racial group, while the individual points represent census tracts. Each panel shows a different borough, allowing us to compare income patterns across NYC’s diverse neighborhoods.

title: Income and Race in New York City
text:
Overall Income Distribution by Race
This violin plot provides a city-wide perspective on income inequality across racial groups. The violin shapes show the density of census tracts at different income levels - wider sections indicate more common income ranges. Racial groups are ordered from lowest to highest median income, making the disparities clearly visible.

title: Income and Race in New York City
text:
Borough-Level Income Comparison
This bar chart enables direct comparison of median incomes across boroughs for each racial group. It reveals whether income gaps exist consistently across all boroughs or vary by geographic location. Only racial groups with sufficient data (5+ census tracts) in each borough are shown to ensure statistical reliability.

title: About This Analysis
text: This project examines income inequality across New York City’s diverse neighborhoods through the lens of race and geography. Using census tract-level data, we analyze median household income patterns across NYC’s five boroughs to understand how economic opportunities vary by both racial demographics and location.

title: About This Analysis
text: This project examines income inequality across New York City’s diverse neighborhoods through the lens of race and geography. Using census tract-level data, we analyze median household income patterns across NYC’s five boroughs to understand how economic opportunities vary by both racial demographics and location.

title: About This Analysis
text:
The Data
Our analysis is based on 2,242 census tract observations across New York City, containing:

Geographic Coverage: All five NYC boroughs (Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island)
Demographic Variables: Racial and ethnic categories including White, Black, Hispanic, and Asian populations
Economic Indicator: Median household income by census tract
Spatial Resolution: Census tract level (the smallest geographic unit for which the Census Bureau publishes sample data)

title: About This Analysis
text:
Why This Matters
Income inequality remains one of the most pressing social and economic issues of our time. New York City, as one of the world’s most diverse metropolitan areas, provides a unique lens for examining how economic opportunities are distributed across different communities. Understanding these patterns is crucial for:

Policy Development: Informing targeted interventions and resource allocation
Community Planning: Identifying areas that may benefit from economic development initiatives

Social Justice: Documenting disparities that affect educational, health, and housing outcomes
Research: Contributing to broader discussions about urban inequality and segregation

title: About This Analysis
text:
Methodology
Our analysis employs three complementary visualization approaches:

Borough-Level Distribution Analysis: Box plots showing income ranges and variability within each racial group across different boroughs
City-Wide Comparison: Violin plots revealing the overall distribution shapes and ranking of racial groups by median income
Cross-Borough Comparison: Bar charts enabling direct comparison of how racial income gaps manifest differently across NYC’s geography

title: About This Analysis
text:
Key Research Questions
This analysis addresses several important questions:

How do income levels vary between racial groups within each NYC borough?
Are income disparities consistent across all boroughs, or do they vary by location?
Which communities have the greatest income variability, and what might this suggest about economic mobility?
How do neighborhood-level patterns contribute to broader metropolitan inequality?

title: About This Analysis
text:
Technical Approach
The analysis was conducted using R with the following key packages: - ggplot2 for data visualization - dplyr for data manipulation and summary statistics - stringr for text processing of geographic identifiers
Data cleaning involved extracting borough information from census tract names and standardizing racial category classifications for consistent analysis.

title: About This Analysis
text:
Limitations and Considerations
While this analysis provides valuable insights, it’s important to note several limitations:

Temporal Snapshot: The data represents a specific time period and may not reflect current conditions
Aggregation Level: Census tract medians may mask within-tract variation
Sample Representation: Some racial groups may have limited representation in certain boroughs
Causation: The analysis describes patterns but does not establish causal relationships

title: About This Analysis
text:
Future Directions
This analysis opens several avenues for deeper investigation: - Temporal trends in income inequality over multiple census periods - Intersection with housing costs and affordability - Relationship between income patterns and access to services, education, and employment opportunities - Integration with other demographic and social indicators

This analysis is part of ongoing research into urban inequality and demographic patterns. For questions about methodology or data sources, please refer to the visualizations and documentation provided.
